Would Farook's mother, and his sisters, who "did not see anything suspicious" be among these decent Muslims?

I am not saying that they are not decent. I am just pointing out that decent Muslims will not necessarily betray their friends and relatives. Only the naïve would rely on them to be our first line of defense.

But then America is fully supplied with naïve people.

Are Republicans wrong to block gun control?

Yes, they are wrong, but the NY Times never points out that California has the strictest gun control laws in the nation. Gun control is good but will not "solve" the problem. It is just NY Times' way of getting back at white males.

If we do not control immigration, and instead worry about the Statue of Liberty shedding tears because we are betraying her, then we only have ourselves to blame for the disasters which are bound to come.

Edward, the couple was firing dozens of high velocity rounds at the police. Did you expect the police to wave a white flag and offer to have a prayer meeting?

A little reality checking is in order here.

ISIS will continue...until and unless the Muslim Global leadership severely and unequivacably denounces and castigates that pathological group and rank and file Muslims around the world demand and work towards their elimination.

The speech was essentially a reiteration of points and strategies the president had enunciated in the past - with one noteworthy exception. For the first time I believe, he acknowledged the elephant in the room - the underwhelming response to date from muslims themselves to the proliferation of extremist ideologies that claim Islam as their authority.

The initial reaction to the Paris attacks, for example, by Australia's muslim leader, Ibrahim Abu Mohammed, was heavily criticized because it was seen as offering justification for the murders. Indeed, reading or listening to muslim leaders as they respond to these brutal acts of terrorism, one is all too often left with an impression of equivocation. And that, I believe, has served to undermine respect for the religion among non-muslims.
Thank you, President Obama for your measured and very considerable thoughtfulness in handling another crisis with no help from Congress and a "chicken little" approach from the republicans.
don't worry, be happy
Switch off CNN which is beating the drums of war as fast as they can. CNN is practically running the Trump campaign for him.
Snip - so is MSNBC, for that matter.

There's this problem of balance.

The President goes on TV once for maybe 15 minutes with a sensible speech about (1) what needs to be done and (2) what should not be done. Not being in his shoes, I would give him the benefit of the doubt on (1), but I don't need to be in his shoes to understand that he was dead right on (2).

Meanwhile, the media give wall-to-wall exposure to his critics. They did it before Paris and San Bernardino and will now predictably do so even more. The critics either just bluster on air 24/7 while having no better ideas, or come out with hotheaded and (faux) macho proposals that if implemented would play right into the hands of ISIS, and would potentially reenact the collapse of the Roman Empire that finally overextended its military reach far beyond its home territory.

There is not a single Republican running for President whom I would trust to take the problem of ISIS and not make it far worse. Not one of them has any magic solution.

Presdient Obama should Keep Calm and Carry On. And the American public should switch off Fox and do the same.
This Wilmer Milksop took out Bin Ladin--something the Republican chicken hawks couldn't do.

@Mor is less
Your rhetoric is far weaker than the President's. Let's hear a sample of the exhortations you would deliver to the Muslim world and the American people. I believe they would only provide the comic relief as seen in your post to an otherwise serious discussion.

You were right in stating that only a more powerful narrative would defeat Da'esh, but one person cannot be the lone voice. Yesterday on Meet the Press I heard the first open conversation about the elephant in the room, Saudi Arabia and its virulent Wahhabist ideology. The leaders of every Western Democracy need to in unison call Saudi Arabia to account for the poison they have let loose on the world.

The main problem with ISIS, is that they don't all live in one place, ready for the US to bomb. They "melt" into the general population. But sending in ground troops means savage hand-to-hand fighting. And how do we determine who is an ISIS member? In WW2, the battles of Iwo Jima and Okinawa were horrific, and we almost killed every single Japanese soldier. This won't be possible with ISIS, in my opinion.
Also, to expect Muslims to rat-out other Muslims is unrealistic.

Bombing Da'esh out of existence is impossible because it us not a country but an ideology. Its weapons are words and narratives. And these weapons are powerful enough to make a woman abandon her baby in order to kill a bunch of infidels. Until the danger is clearly understood, we are going to blunder around, bombing wrong people and invading wrong countries. The only weapon powerful enough to defeat a narrative us another narrative but President Obsma is unable to wield it. His rhetoric is pedestrian at best, embarrassing at worst. He cannot speak the right words to stir the hearts of freedom-loving people at home and in the Muslim world. Such people exist but they are not "moderate believers" (whatever that is). They are cultural Muslims who are tired of the Sharia law, want to join the modern world, and are eager to hear the unapologetic, full-throated defense of the universal values of freedom, democracy, reason, and science. Unfortunately Obama is not the one to deliver it.

More gun control is not the answer.  California has some of the most stringent gun control laws in the country and, they don't prevent the continued use of firearms. So, how do you plan to increase gun control?  The problem is the people who use those firearms.  What evidence do you have that a majority of NRA members are open to gun proposals?  It sounds like pure fantasy at best.

Gun control is not more than rhetorically on the table, thanks to the NRA and cowardly members of Congress. Yet polls evidently demonstrate that a majority of NRA members are open to gun control proposals.

Given this circumstance, can we hope for an uprising by the NRA rank and file? Perhaps the NRA leadership would become flexible about reasonable gun control measures if their jobs are threatened.

I found Obama’s words of little comfort.  I found the phrasing of terrorism as something to “overcome”  odd.  Did it come from the African-American civil rights anthem "We Shall Overcome” I wonder?  I remember as a child, when singing, “Deep In My Heart, I Do Believe, We Shall Overcome Someday’…that I never believed it. I just figured it was the adults way of saying it’ll never happen, but make the best of it.
What's your solution? If you've got something more than a long rant and a whine, let's hear it.
His solution = Hot air!

To JGalt/LA.
Nick Metrowsky makes many points that most Americans are asking or are otherwise pondering today. Your rather snide "And your solutions are?" shows nothing. What are YOUR solutions?

noun

The tiresome nature of finger pointing and putting money (Gun Lobby, NRA) ahead of national security and public safety. Restricting travel of Americans, while at the same time have a very lax visa policy. Focusing on those coming in from south of the border, and not the real problem.

Washington politicians, and their parties, Americans are not scared, they are angered over complete incompetence, self serving greed and political self indulgence of those who us suppose to keep this country safe.

Tonight was the same broken record from all political sides, and the complete ineptitude by our politicians and president wanna bes.

So where is America scared? Knowing that when we wake up tomorrow, the political rhetoric and grand standing will continue. meanwhile, someone, or a group of someones, will be arming themselves for the next mass shooting de jour or something worse.

We mean the way Bush/Cheney administration did? They were the original "botchers". Without their foray in to Iraq this mess would not have happened. The GOP has much to be condemned for in its jingoism and swagger. Time for an apology to the world - a real, heartfelt one.
Blaming Bush?  Seriously?  It is 2015 not 2008
Thank you for reminding us what passes for "thinking" on the right.

It's been a long times since Obama's tough talk has calmed anyone.  We all know he is all talk and no action.  Now his botched handling of Syria has come home to roost as the apotheosis of the his failed Middle East policies - the nail in the coffin of the failed Obama presidency.

According to some comments here, the fact Obama signed off with "God bless the United States of America" and had Christmas decorations in the White House is one of the reasons ISIS is mad at us. Maybe we should cease all form of religious expression and then they'll stop attacking us?!

Mrs. Clinton is a Democrat. Ergo "she cannot be wrong and if she appears to be wrong then it must be Republican propaganda".

What can I say? The NYT is just as insane as the Republicans it is constantly criticizing.

Of course Libya and the disaster that followed, to Gaddafi, to the US ambassador and to millions of Libyans and Syrians are on the head of our president and Mrs. Clinton. But it is not going to be admitted here at the NYT which has exchanged truth and analysis for partisanship.

Any chance that you might run for president?
I am NOT kidding. Someone needs to pay attention to you!!

I wonder when America, Britain, France and Russia are going to declare the war on the ISIS. They haven’t done absolutely anything over the last several years.

The first serious step in this war is the instant resignation of Obama, Cameron, Hollande and Putin for being utterly incompetent. The most important trait of the great leaders is their ability to motivate their citizens. If they can’t do it, they are incapable of leading their countries.

It’s hard to believe that all of them are so ineffective. Some of their countrymen leave their families, their jobs, their homes, and their friends, spend several thousand dollars to travel to Syria only to fight their and most probably die.

Why have our leaders failed to offer something better to those fooled individuals? What has al-Baghdadi that our leaders don’t have at their disposal?

The Koran?!

The Koran belongs to the leaders of the great powers and the rest of the world as much as to the leader of ISIS. The difference is that the latter is using the Holy Book but our leaders failed to understand anything within the Koran.

The Koran is the best, cheapest and most efficient way to destroy the ISIS and the terrorism.

Over the last 14 years I have made many offers to our government to teach them how to deploy the Koran in the fight against the al-Qaeda and the ISIS but they never replied to my emails or showed any interest…

I could have never understood such colossal hubris and ignorance…

On the assumption that edward is not joking, the couple managed to shoot 75 rounds of ammunition of the almost unlimited supply in their car. They managed to wound one policeman. It is difficult to imagine capturing them alive by any means without the use of hypnotism.

Lorens, A couple of points in re your comment:

First, I cannot remember the last time that President Obama gave "a hell of a speech," but I imagine that it was sometime in 2008.

Second, if only he were "reactionary." I was taught, in high school American Government (by a PHENOMENAL teacher named Cal Schenkel), that the word "reactionary" applied to the far right. In other words, the FIRST time that ISIS/ISIL/fill-in-the-blank committed any act of terrorism, would also be the LAST. (At least for the time being -- I do understand that.)

I was a political science major. My beliefs depend upon the issue. But concerning terrorism, the tried and true phrase "nip it in the bud" has never loomed greater. Our president has absolutely no idea how to handle the part of his job that is "Commander-in-Chief." He can rattle on about "good Muslims." That is NOT the issue. (And, note that none of the "good Muslims" have STOPPED the catastrophe going on in the name of Islam.)

Yes, Lorens, he is supposed to be a leader. He is not. Typically, Americans know how to LEAD . We've done it before, and we have to do it again.

Remember, it's "We the People."

Excuse me, but I believe any failure in Iraq and Afghanistan, can be laid at the feet of Bush & Cheney.
Isis is made up of the people in Saddam Husseins army— they wouldn't exist if our "strategy" back then wasn't a cosmic, horrific blunder.

@Lorens: "This is the same president who failed in Iraq - he followed the exit strategy presented by his predecessor. Last time I checked he was supposed to be a leader, not a follower."

What you refuse to understand that Iraq is a sovereign country led by OUR puppet, installed by Bush, who declined to extend our Staus of Forces Agreement despite extensive pressure from the Obama Administration. Staying would have been a de facto invasion.

"My dog has a better foresight."

Better foresight would have been NOT to have invaded Iraq in the FIRST place, or does your dog also see the world through partisan glasses?

I have to remind myself that this is the same president who couldn't even attend the Charlie Hebdo peace rally with the rest of the world powers, not even letting the VP or a main diplomat represent the United States.

This is the same president who failed in Iraq - he followed the exit strategy presented by his predecessor. Last time I checked he was supposed to be a leader, not a follower.

Yes he can give a hell of a speech, but please, he is completely reactionary in his domestic and foreign policy.

My dog has a better foresight.

Unless and until we are willing to face the facts that Saudi Arabia and other Rich ME countries are bank rolling have have been bank rolling these murderers and do something about it like freeze their assets and ban their travel into the West we will never contain these murderers. Theocrats of all stripes have one goal to control everyone and make them submit. We don't want to accept that but we must if we are to craft any real solutions!

Gun control in our own country is an important part of controlling terrorism whether it comes from Muslims or Christians who would kill to enforce their view of the world and force others to accept it. Ideas matter and judgement matters. When we refuse to make judgements, we disarm ourselves.

Are more guns really the answer?  The shooters used military-style long guns which were modified to make them more lethal.  What good is a hand gun against that?  Last week I read about a little girl who found a gun stuffed into a sofa and managed to shoot herself.  Too often children are the victims of carelessness on the part of parents who don't secure their guns in the home. In another case a man was killed at a gun show-a friend pointed and fired a weapon which happened to be loaded.  Basic gun safety (never point a weapon at another person, treat it as if were loaded, etc) is not being practiced/ taught when people examine guns for purchase.  More guns are not the answer.  Bring back common sense in gun ownership.  Stop the NRA from poisoning people's minds.

You assume that one handgun would be the response to an armed criminal or terrorist. You will probably not read reports like this one below in the Times, given its ideological propaganda against our 2nd Amendment right. But you will find them in the Washington Post. See this Eugene Volokh report of civilians stopping armed gunmen with armed responses:https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/volokh-conspiracy/wp/2015/10/03/do-c...
Clearly, citizens acting in legal self-defense have used multiple handguns to stop criminal gunmen, just as several law enforcement officers did in San Bernardino. Many guns prevail over one gun, even if it is an assault rifle. For some gun owners, self-defense in concealed carry guns is as much an expression of their religion as it is for Sikhs or Omanis permitted to carry knives.

"The shooters used military-style long guns which were modified to make them more lethal."

How so? The media has not reported that they had modified the guns into automatics which is the only enhancement possible. Have you a news source the rest of us don't?

I am proud that the Statue of Liberty holds up her torch in the city of my birth, NYC. The GOP candidates and Speaker Ryan seem to have no feasible solutions only more fear-mongering and gun worshipping.

PS. 185,000 guns were purchased on Black Friday..to add to the 300 million we already own.

Blaming the US is as misguided as blaming guns. The cause of this new effort to recreate the caliphate is the dissolution of the last one. The US has nothing to do with it.

The one thing Obama consistently gets wrong is his depiction of ISIL as "thugs". That's a serious miscalculation, right up there with calling it the "JV team". It's a well funded effort, led by skilled people with hundreds of millions of US dollars behind it. (It robbed an Iraqi bank and got over $400 million.)

He doesn't have to get all excited and use a tough-sounding voice, but he does have to get it right.
Frank - neither one worked out well. However, it now appears that the Mr. Obama will cause much deeper and longer lasting damage.

As for Ms. TRAINOR, I'll presume this wasn't true in Israel, but there was a time when it was impossible in this country to avoid her song about THAT Bass. Ms. TRAINOR had done very well for herself from an early age writing songs for other performers; but for this particular song, her manager or someone thought she would be the best to sing it (although she has self-doubt about her voice). The song and the video were played repeatedly.

And that leads us to GAUNT! Some thought Ms. TRAINOR's song counteracted "fat-shaming" (the criticism of Rubenesque female physiques), although feminists don't interpret it that way. But some say the linguistic battle should be about discouraging any word -- GAUNT, e.g. -- that seems to refer negatively to a person's healthy weight.

As for Lincoln, you are right, but some doctors playing retrospective medical detective have asserted for various reasons that Lincoln's weight WAS unhealthy as a result of some syndrome; others say JFK was unhealthily thin as a result of a different disease but that the steroids he took for it kept him from looking GAUNT.

P.S. When Ms. TRAINOR sings all about THAT bass, it's an anatomical metaphor, as is "no treble".

We need to step away, far away and let the Muslims in the ME resolve their differences or not but we can no longer guard them against the consequences of THEIR BELIEFS AND THEIR CHOICES.

Excellent point, Felix Pepper.

The lesson of France is that gun control works. That's why gun violence is comparatively rare in France, and why it took a concerted, international conspiracy to smuggle guns into France: you can't get them there, so you have to buy them in Belgium.

The lesson of San Bernardino is that easy access to guns means more deaths. And spare me the nonsense about California's "restrictive" gun laws: you can't speak of meaningful gun control when anyone can get a military grade semi-automatic weapon on demand and give it his neighbor. If California's laws are the toughest in the nation, it's only because the bar is so low.
